content.description: The crux is pulling the bulge low on the route.  There is sustained climbing thereafter.
content.location: Located about 40' to the right of "Sail Bait".  Starts down low by the creek.

climbs.name: Tenshun
climbs.fa: J. Steiger, C. & J. Saviers-Steiger, June 16, 2007

content.description:
This route climbs the steepest crack line on the narrow north buttress of Upper Creekside.  Scamble up to a wide crack and work up face holds just right to a steep thin crack that eventually protects moves over a small bulge to lower angle climbing above.

This is not in Bingham's 2004 ed. guide and some of the placements needed to be cleaned out, so it appears most likely a FA.  My partners (ages 9 and 11) thought it was 5.8.
content.location:
Approximately 60 feet left of

Old Timer

, around the corner on the north buttress facing the south buttress of the Anteater.  Descend by rapping from the anchors atop

This Spud's For You

(tricky to get to and requires at least a 70m rope) or the anchors on top of one of the Office routes.

content.description: Climb a wide crack/corner system that starts in a right facing corner. It eases up after the second bulge, which is BD C4 #4 - 5 size with some slopey, gritty feet on the face, but doable at ye olde 5.8. Then follow the obvious line up and right.
content.protection: A C4 #4 or two and a 5 could be useful if this is a difficult grade for you, but plentiful options exist for the upper part. Build your own anchor (there is also a nice thread for the belay).
content.location: Located between Elfworks and Dire Straights in the right facing corner (had stinging nettle in the crack near the bottom when we did it). Walk off to the east down slabs directly opposite the climb, then around the north side to return to the base.

content.description: A decent route on good rock.  Crux is down low.
content.location: The first bolted line the right of "Pogemahone".

content.description: A fun route with a good variety of climbing. Follow the bolts up the slab to a fun overlap/bulge. The route then turns steeper as you approach the chains.
content.protection: 9 Bolts, Chain anchor. Optional small cams to supplement a few mildly spaced out bolts on the upper half of the route (0.2-0.5).
content.location: Look for bolts roughly 15 feet right of Corner Kick.

content.description:
Ho hum.  Guidebook gives it 5.9, but it felt more like 5.7 to my partner and I.  Worth doing once if in the neighborhood, but I won't be back.  As a "5.7 handcrack", this is an excellent climb.  As a "5.9 handcrack", it was a bit of a let down.

A long, right trending handcrack.  Lots of face holds keep the difficulty in check.

Rap anchors are located to the North and are difficult to spot.  They are on top of "This Spuds For You".  Locate them before starting up the route as you can see them from the ground.  A 70m rope JUST makes the ground.
content.location: Located on the Upper Creekside as can be easily identified as a long, right trending handcrack just right of two parallel cracks.

content.description:
This long route is a 3-star pump with great steep climbing on a patina covering face.  It is only marred by a couple hard to clip bolts.

Start by scrambling up a short chimney to the left of the climb.  It is the first climb on the exposed ledge on the left.  The pumpy crux comes in the first 4 bolts through steep terrian. The crux is clipping the 4th bolt, since it was placed to the right of the best holds.  The bolts above are well spaced, which will keep you on your toes.

You can lower with a 60M, but your belayer need to be on the upper ledge at the start of the climb. With a 70M you can lower to the ground.
content.location: This is the fourth route from the right edge of the west side of Creekside.

content.description: An understated classic! Nairobi throws multiple cruxes at you - kicking off with pumpy, off-balance moves departing a block and committing to the face before traversing right and moving up past several tough bulges. The anchors, which are clipped from from a mail slot jug, are guarded by an improbable but brilliant crux move. Steep, slabby goodness and possibly high in the grade.
content.protection: 9 bolts. Having the draws in place (and possibly a few long draws) takes the sting out of this route. Otherwise clean airtime is definitely possible!

content.description: This is a great route that opens with tough laybacks and reaches for the first three bolts before easing up with enjoyable, steep climbing to the anchor. Perfect rock.
content.protection: Five bolts. The cautious may wish for a few cams to protect the opening climbing and stretches between bolts, but anyone capable of climbing the route should have no problem doing it with just draws.
content.location: Begin on a SW-facing wall with beautiful patina and irregular vertical seams and cracks. Boulder up a hand-crack/flake to reach the first bolt.

content.description:
Climb the water runnel where the slab gets steeper. Here, you can place small gear to protect moves out right on good holds. Continue upwards on easy ground to the base of two crack systems. Here, you can pick one of two options:

1) The left parallel cracks in the dihedral climb at 5.6 and appear to be what is described in Bingham's book (although the picture shows the route taking the right crack)

2) The right splitter hand crack can be climbed at ~5.8

Build an anchor at the top of your crack system of choice, then walk off to the Beeline chains to rappel.

An alternative start includes clipping the first two bolts of Beeline to protect the initial runout before moving right across the water runnel.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches. Single rack is fine. Gear anchor. Easy to rap from Beeline with a 60m.
content.location:
​​​​Immediately left of

Double Trouble

on the slab.

content.description: Contrived but fun, exactly how it is described in the guidebook.  Begin up a 5.8 corner (Strawberry Jam) and then step left to the first bolt.  Interesting climbing through varied terrain, including a steep headwall move at the end gets you to the chains.   Not a classic, but still fun in you are in the neighborhood.
content.protection: Bolts to chain anchor.  Hand size cams optional to get to the first bolt.
content.location: Locate Dire Straights and/or Strawberry Jam.  This climb is just left of Strawberry Jam, and starts up that climb for about 20' then wanders left on a catwalk passed the first and second bolts.  The bolts go straight up from there.

content.description: In the latest guidebook this route is named Double Cracks, 5.8, trad., gear to 3"

This climb is listed as being in the "lower creekside" area in the Bingham guide. Walk a bit down from double trouble and those other climbs. Start on a boulder for varied climbing to the top of the formation. Climbs much better than it looks. Felt like an old school route. Probably doesn't get climbed much.  We walked off the back side but may be possible to reach some rap anchors of neighboring sport climbs or of those in The Closet

This route is mostly an EZ hike until the top where there's maybe a couple 5.6 moves.  A bit mossy, untraveled, gritty, and not very esthetic.  So what's the lure?  Well, when you top out, you realize you either have to walk off or donate some webbing/biners to rap off a horn.  You cannot get to the top of the chains like you would for Ramp and Double Cracks.  I chose the walk off as I'm cheap.  It should be fairly evident that only a moron with nothing better to do would do this route just by looking at it.  But, as an excuse, I was playing guide to a horde of midgets and thought this and the 2 routes to the left would work well to keep them occupied and thinking of things other than circus abuse from the carnies.
content.protection: Widgets and dirty carbuncles that clang together in the night.

content.description:
This is a mostly bolted line left of Calderbone's

Enter the Fold.

This offers a sane way to climb that route or is a good line in it's own right.  It felt 5.6 or less except for 1 move by bolt 2.  Another good moderate for the area.  Thanks Duane!
content.protection: 7-8 bolts, 1 or 2 cams (.4-2), and chain anchors. The crack up top is EZ-land if you are strictly a spurt climber and don't have any gear.
content.location: Look for very well camouflaged bolts on the slab.  Keep looking, they're there somewhere.  This line heads straight up to the 20' finger crack up high to a chain anchor.
